The Chapter on Abandoning the Body, Part 7, 22 people in the main biographies, 2 people in the attached biographies, the biography of Monk Cang of Fenzhou in the Tang Dynasty, the biography of Monk Cang of Fenzhou in the Tang Dynasty, Monk Cang, a monk from Xihe.
He left secular life at a young age, with a noble character and clear spirit. He was truly virtuous and kind, and was humble in his position.
When he received the precepts and goodness, he secretly protected his faculties and objects.
If he saw a temple, he would definitely pay homage. If he encountered a great virtuous one, he would pay homage to the utmost.
If he encountered laypeople or monks offering prostrations, he would bow and run away, as if avoiding the long-lived ones.
If he was in the midst of the duties of the assembly, he would humble himself like a menial worker, as if he had obtained something valuable.
If he saw other people's old clothes, he would secretly wash and mend them.

Even in the scorching heat, he would take off his clothes and enter the grass and bushes, enduring the bites of mosquitoes, horseflies, and leeches, with their stings and blood flowing, sweating with pain.
Yet he constantly recited the name of AmitÄbha Buddha, even the most skilled astrologer could not determine the number.
His determination and concentration were never lacking.
When he knew his life was coming to an end, he said to those who were tending to him:
This mountain monk has been fortunate to have the heavenly beings come to welcome me in turn.
Zang also said:
When I close my eyes and hear the flowers being scattered by the gathering of the most virtuous people in the Pure Land, I will return here and then give up my life.
With palms joined, he peacefully passed away while reciting the Buddha's name.

The Biography of Zhengshou of Guang Temple in Handong Mountain during the Tang Dynasty, the Biography of Zhengshou of Guang Temple in Handong Mountain during the Tang Dynasty, the Biography of Zao Chan Master Shi Zhengshou, who was from an unknown place.
His appearance was lofty and dignified, his character was lofty and strong, carrying his staff and traveling with his bag, he visited all the Chan masters.
However, due to the resonance of causes and conditions, he attached himself to the gate of Chan Master Nantatou, resolved his web of doubts, and secretly cultivated and benefited.

At that time, Prince Qiao Chongfu, the second son of the late emperor, was slandered by Wei Zhongkan in the early years of the Shenlong era, saying he had colluded with the Zhang brothers to commit serious crimes.
He was transferred to the post of Prefect of Junzhou, closely guarded, and not allowed to see visitors.

After Wei was executed, Emperor Xuanzong ascended the throne and transferred him to the post of Prefect of Jizhou.
Before he could take up the post, he suddenly became unhappy and turned his heart to Chan Master Zao, having him build a pagoda for his relics, seventy feet tall, extremely grand and magnificent.
At that time, Master Zao was already gravely ill. Prince Qiao asked the master, Who will succeed you after your passing?
Zao said:
I still have a proper lifespan.
The king asked the monks:
Who has a proper lifespan?
Some said:
The master has a disciple named Shan Guang, who hides his traces in the mountains.
The king sent messengers to summon him. Shou told Master Zhao:
I am happy that the king is a patron. The pagoda has already been completed. May I try it first, or not?
Zhao said:
Good, try it for me.

At that time, Shou put on his robe, joined his palms, entered the pagoda, closed his eyes, sat in the full lotus position, and immediately entered nirvana. His entire body did not scatter. At that time, he was called the Trial Pagoda Monk.
When King Qiao heard this, he sighed all day, saying:
Even a disciple is like this!
He then discussed changing the plan and building it for Chan Master Zhao.
The author says:
Before others have the intention to take away, Master Shou has already taken away from Zhao.

Those who go straight forward are sure to be able to go straight back - not bound by karmic burdens, not trapped in the cage of afflictions, escaping the bonds and opening the cage, free in birth and death.
If one is already free, one has already attained the stage of fruition.
From the perspective of worldly truth, Master Shou is the blue that comes from indigo.

Zhanran then only carried his water bottle and staff, and solely burned famous incense. He ordered Zhao Hua of Ji clan to bring two rolls of wax cloth, a bundle of coarse hemp, and one dou of fragrant juice, and on the top of Zhongtai, from dawn to dusk, he paid homage and burned incense, with little rest, and did not eat or drink at all, reciting the Buddha's name with sincere reverence, his voice uninterrupted.
By the deep hour of the night, Zhao Hua wondered why, and climbed up the steep peak, seeing Zhanran still in his original place, even more focused.
Zhanran said to Zhao Hua:

Zhao followed his instructions without any change, and from the top to the feet, it finally collapsed.
Zhao sighed and said:
In the past, I heard of the Medicine King burning his body, and now I see the superior person. How strange!
How painful!
Later, the disciples collected the true bones and built a stupa to the south of Brahma Sage Mountain, which is still there today.

The Biography of Dinglan of Fugan Temple in Chengdu Prefecture of the Tang Dynasty, the Biography of Dinglan of Fugan Temple in Chengdu Prefecture of the Tang Dynasty, Shi Dinglan, whose surname was Yang, was from Chengdu.
He was originally a violent butcher in the market, but Heaven bestowed him with a nature to repent of his past wrongs, vowing to participate in the six harmonies and transform the three Shu regions.
At that time, everyone believed in him.
He built a monastery called Shengshou.
Before the conditions were ready, he hid it among the hired guards.
His parents passed away early, and he had no resources to offer for the deceased.

Whenever it was his parents' death anniversary, Lan would cry until he lost his voice, and then he would go naked into Qingcheng Mountain, allowing mosquitoes, horseflies, and flies to bite his skin, saying, I offer my inner wealth to repay their hard work.
In Shu, there were black and white frogs, shaped like millet, that would bite people's flesh, but they were rarely seen.
Next, he wrote scriptures with his blood, and later he burned his arm. He also pulled out his ears and gouged out his eyes to feed to predatory birds and beasts.
Then, when walking, he would stumble into things without support.
Later, a strange person held something in his palm like a pearl, placed it in the empty eye socket, and in a moment, the eye could see as before.
The strange person said in a mysterious way:
The southern heavenly king has returned your eye.
The people near and far were shocked.
He often said to people:
I have heard in the Sutra of Good Precepts that it is called the unsurpassed giving - I vow to diligently practice and quickly attain the supreme fruit.
In the third year of the Daming era, Emperor Xuanzong issued an edict inviting him to the inner palace for offerings, respecting him with superior etiquette because of his spiritual responses.
His disciple Yuanying always attended to his left and right.
In the second month of the sixth year, he again vowed to burn his shoulders.
The emperor repeatedly advised him, saying that he was old and should focus on long-term cultivation and refinement.
Lan did not follow the edict and burned himself to death.
Yuanying memorialized, requesting to change his name and build a stupa. The emperor posthumously bestowed the title of Enlightened Nature and the stupa was named True Enlightenment.
People in the capital of Shu still call it Dinglan Pagoda Temple, and it is said that incense and offerings have never ceased.
The Biography of Hongxiu of Jianfu Temple on Mount Huangbo in Fuzhou, Tang Dynasty. The Biography of Jingxian Hongxiu, a monk of unknown origin.
His spiritual bearing was outstanding, and his profound mind was in motion. He lived in the Huangbo monastery in Min, surrounded by a multitude of monks.
Apart from teaching, he was always cheerful and joyful.
He often said:
Past debts must be repaid. Once repaid, then what worries and fears are there?
Both things and I are freely roaming.
People all did not understand his meaning.
When the chaos of the Guangming era arrived, the bandit nests were filled with chaos. Xiu left the temple, took off his patched robe under a pine tree on a flat rock, and said:
I vow not to defile the pure land.
And calmly drew his neck to await the blade. There was no blood under the blade. The bandits were shocked and awed, and prostrated themselves in repentance.
His disciples Jingxian cremated his body, collected seven relics, and treasured them in a pouch.
A devout believer tried to exchange them with beans the size of grains, but could not catch up with him. He then went to consult an oracle, which said:
Life and death, noble and humble, are not distinguished in my divination.
In the loss of being and non-being, the loss of peace and chaos.
Who knows the reason for this?
When it was obtained, it was placed in a stupa, divided into seven grains, and sealed in a glass vessel, shining with a radiant color.
At that time, monk Qing Huai wrote a text and composed a verse to record his virtues.

The Biography of Shi Quan Huang of Yan Tou Temple in Ezhou during the Tang Dynasty, the Biography of Shi Quan Huang of Yan Tou Temple in Ezhou during the Tang Dynasty, Shi Quan Huang, a layman surnamed Ke, was a person from Quanzhou.
From a young age, he was outstanding, with a vast and simple temperament.
He paid respects to Qing Yuan Yi Gong as his teacher.
He went to Chang'an and entered Xi Ming Temple, where he received the complete precepts under Master Zhao.
He then studied the sutras and vinaya at Bao Shou Temple on the left street, discerning the fundamental principles. He was about to become a lecturer and guide, shaking his staff southward.
He went to De Shan in Wu Ling.
The medicine and illness corresponded, and he had no more doubts or hindrances.
Later, he lived in a cave next to Dongting Lake, which was called Sleeping Dragon, and built a room there to rest.
His disciples followed him like shadows.
He also lived on Mount Tangnian, on which there was a rocky cliff, and built an abbey there, calling it Yan Tou.
In all his actions, he simplified and unified, sitting upright, letting the crowd surround him, saying:
Why don't you contemplate?
There are so many things in the household, but in the realm of adversity and favor, you truly attain the characteristics of transcendence.

During the Guangqi period, there were many events in the Central Plains, and the feudal lords competed with each other. Bandits came to plunder, and everyone avoided them, but Huai remained calm as usual.
The bandits accused him of not providing offerings, and angrily ordered him to be beheaded, but he showed no fear on his face.

Biography of Yuanhui of Fawang Temple in Jiaxing, Wuzhou, Tang Dynasty Biography of Yuanhui of Fawang Temple in Jiaxing, Wuzhou, Tang Dynasty Shi Yuanhui, with the secular surname Lu, was a descendant of Ji, the Grand Master of Pingyuan in the Jin dynasty.
His father Dan, the Prefect of Wenzhou, was a Gentleman-in-Attendance and Cavalry Attendant-in-Ordinary. Yuanhui was his second son.
He was exceptionally intelligent from a young age, and grew up to be gentle and refined. He feared becoming a withered turtle, and wished to be a lean goose.
In the second year of Kaihuang, he took leave of his parents and became a disciple of Qingjin at Fawang Temple.
In the first year of Huichang, he went to Hengyang to receive the precepts and began to study the Vinaya.
He entered to pay homage to the Five Terrace Mountains and also visited the auspicious signs.

In the second year, he returned to Jiahe to visit his relatives and stayed at Jianxing Temple, determined to uphold the three pure precepts and chant the five divisions of the maá¹‡á¸ala, burning incense on his arm.
In the fifth year, he was affected by the purge and temporarily hid in lay clothes.
In the beginning of the Dazhong era, he returned to the Dharma gate.
In the seventh year, he rebuilt the Fawang Temple.
He also burned incense on his arm to make offerings to the Buddha's tooth relic on Mount Baoen.
Next, he went to Mount Tiantai, crossed the stone bridge, and benefited wherever he went, without any worries or fears.
In the Xiané€š era, he followed the Buddha's middle finger bone relic to Chongzhen Temple in Fengxiang.
He refined his left thumb, recited the Lotus Sutra, and his finger grew back in less than a month as if it had never been injured.
In the third year of Qianning, he suddenly said he was unwell.
On the twenty-eighth day of the ninth month, he passed away at the Zunshen Temple, at the age of seventy-eight, and had been a monk for fifty-eight years.
His disciples, Duan Su and others, respectfully buried his remains in Wu and Hui, calling him the Third White Monk.
His prostrations, recitations, and practices are countless, as recorded elsewhere.
The author says:
Refining the thumb, the fire is exhausted and the ashes fly away, how can bones and flesh grow again soon as before at the end of the burnt charcoal?

These three whites are not black karma.
Therefore, it is called by this name.

Biography of Ming, a Monk of the Hermitage in Nanyue during the Tang Dynasty. The Biography of Ming, a Monk of the Hermitage in Nanyue during the Tang Dynasty. Shi Ming, a monk of secular surname Lu, was from Changzhou, Wuzhong.
He studied with a teacher in his hometown when he was young, and later traveled around to inquire about the Way. However, he was upright and lofty, whistling and frolicking on his own.
He first visited Wutai and Emei Mountains, paying homage to the golden and silver world bodhisattvas, who all manifested themselves according to his mind.
From there, he climbed Tiantai, ascended Luofu, entered Hengyue, and visited Zizhong.
During the late Tang dynasty, the areas to the left and right of Xiang were divided and fought, seeking peace but never achieving it, with no peaceful years.
Thus, he took up residence at the foot of Mount Zhuluo, with the intention of spending his final years there.
He stayed at Qibaotai, forming a close friendship with Xuantong.
Xuantong never opposed his likes and dislikes, nor did he question his importance.
He once said to his fellow practitioners:
I do not wish to be burned on a wooden tower like Sengya, nor do I want to be buried in a fish's belly like Qu Yuan.
In the end, I vow to cast off my body, learning from Prince Sadaprarudita who transcended many kalpas to attain sagehood. Isn't this something to strive for?
He spoke of this repeatedly, but no one believed him.
Suddenly, in the midst of the forest, he threw himself in front of a ferocious tiger, which fought with others to eat him, and in an instant, the flesh was gone.
At that time, Master Xuantong collected his remaining bones and cremated them, and obtained relics.
He then picked flowers, poured water, and wrote a text to offer sacrifices to him.

The words clarify its bravery, able to abandon internal wealth, destroy stinginess, and accomplish the perfection of generosity. Before giving, after giving, and in the act of giving, the three wheels are suddenly emptied, and the great fruit is obtained as easily as picking up a mustard seed.
The author says:
The Buddha ordered the monks to give food to sentient beings, benefiting both the present and future lives, and the resulting rewards are not light.
If the lord official accomplishes the great perfection of generosity, he will be far from stinginess and greed;
he will accomplish great bravery and attain fearlessness;
he will accomplish the emptiness of the three wheels and the merit of non-action;
he will accomplish the difficult mind of giving and purify the Buddha land.
In one throw of his body, his benefits are vast!
It is like a good rewarder who spends little but encourages much. Is this what it means?
Shi Xichen, whose surname was Yang, was a person from Bingzhou.
His father engaged in buying and selling, only concerned with making profits.
His mother once dreamed that a person in magnificent attire came to stay overnight, and then she became pregnant.
When born, he was extraordinary, not like an ordinary child.
Whenever he heard the sound of bells and chants, he would concentrate and listen with ears pricked up.
When he was twelve years old, he had a dream of a magnificent person leading him into a magnificent hall.
The next morning, he told his parents about it and earnestly requested to leave home and become a monk.
Before his parents agreed, he cried and refused to eat.
His parents pitied his natural disposition and did not want to block his aspirations, so they reluctantly consented.
He then went to Caotang Temple and followed his teacher to recite the VimalakÄ«rti-nirdeÅ›a-sÅ«tra and the Bodhisattva Precepts. He did not sleep all night.
When he was about to complete one year, he memorized the entire text.
When he was seventeen, he attended lectures on the VimalakÄ«rti-nirdeÅ›a-sÅ«tra and roughly understood its main meaning.
When he reached the age of twenty, he completed the highest level of precepts and upheld the Vinaya rules without any lapses.
At the age of twenty-three, he thoroughly understood the literary meaning and received the transmission from Dharma Master Zonggan of Chongfu Temple.
He further studied logic and consciousness-only, and did not neglect to expound them, with several outstanding students.
Dengzun of Chongfu Temple was his most accomplished disciple.
In the second year of Tianyou, the Li family occupied Hedong, and Emperor Wu invited him to reside in the Pure Land Institute of Dangan Temple, providing him with the four requisites.
He specialized in reading the Buddhist canon and cultivating the practice of rebirth in the Pure Land. He held an unrestricted great vegetarian feast, with five sessions in total.
Chen once fed his body to wolves and tigers, entering the mountains and valleys, and the beasts approached, sniffed, and ran away.
He also bared his body in the woods to feed mosquitoes and gadflies.
Then he visited Xianyan Yue Temple to nurture the Way and dwell in the spirit.
He again read through the Buddhist canon, held a vegetarian feast, and burned a finger to express his gratitude.
In the temple, there was a sacred image of Avalokitesvara Bodhisattva, which was always lit with seven lamps, with incense and flowers offered.
Later, he was invited by the people to go down the mountain, and he expounded the great treatises in the city, without stopping for the four seasons.
Every month, he set up bathing facilities by the river, and fed the aquatic creatures in the ponds;
He used his own donations to redeem birds and animals - the lofty and bright ones were able to follow their natural instincts.
Sometimes he provided food for prisoners, sometimes he gave aid to the poor, and sometimes he donated banners and canopies to the Jingming and Jinsang stupas.
In the second year of the Longxing era of the Later Tang dynasty, the assembly invited him to build three academies behind the Great An Guo Temple, to provide for the listeners from all directions.
At that time, he also lectured on the new Huayan Sutra and transmitted it to Dharma Master Ji Hui of Chongfu Temple.
Therefore, for three years, he did not leave the academy gate, and bowed once for each word in the Huayan Sutra once, and bowed for each word in the Great Buddha's Name Sutra, a total of 120 volumes.
He burned another finger, totaling five fingers burned in all.
At that time, the founding emperor of the Jin dynasty was in hiding in Jinyang, and had the utmost admiration and respect for Chen.
After he ascended the throne, Chen often entered the capital to pay his respects, and was always invited to the inner palace to relax. He was generously rewarded.
The emperor bestowed purple robes and honorable titles upon him, but he firmly declined.

Chen heard that the Famen Temple in Fengxiang Prefecture had the true body of a Buddha's middle finger bone, so he took leave of the emperor to go to Qizhou to pay homage. Seeing its rarity, he burned another finger.
Chen had only two fingers left on both hands.
He then studied the Abhidharma-koÅ›a SÅ«tra with Dharma Master Chulun at Tianzhu Temple.

After several days, he developed a slight illness. On the twenty-seventh day of the seventh month, he passed away while leaning on his elbow. He was sixty-three years old in the secular world and forty-four years old as a monk.
In his daily life, he only wore coarse cloth and did not accumulate excess wealth.
He performed the six periods of worship to the Buddha without the slightest omission.
When the people between Longdi heard of his passing, the black and white assemblies all came to send him off to be cremated. They obtained several hundred grains of Å›arÄ«ra.
His disciples took his relics back to Taiyuan. The Jin ancestor ordered them to be buried on the western mountain of Jinshui. The small pagoda still exists today.
The author says:
How can abandoning one's body surpass one's diligence?
How can renouncing floating glory surpass one's understanding of the meaning?
If so, one cannot be named by a single name.
It is like the champak flower, which is yellow and beautiful, then true gold rejects its color;
Its fragrance is far-reaching, then oxhead is ashamed of its fragrance.
The one who gives rise to many names from a single body is the Venerable Chen!

Biography of Dao Yu of Pingtian Temple on Mount Tiantai of the Jin Dynasty, Biography of Dao Yu of Pingtian Temple on Mount Tiantai of the Jin Dynasty, Shi Dao Yu was a person from the country of Silla. His surname in his native country is unknown.
Since the Renzi year of the Jingfu era of the Tang dynasty, he traveled to Tiantai and stayed at the main hall of Putian Temple.
He treated people with kindness and love, but he never gave up speaking in the barbarian language.
He always held a bowl to receive food, and after eating, he would briefly walk around and always sit, not lying down.
At noon, he would sweep the halls and take care of the permanent residence;
he would collect leftover food, even if it was of poor color or had changed smell, and store it in a container to eat at mealtime.
He provided bathing and tea for the monks, and when he encountered living creatures in the firewood, he would put them far away on the ground, taking special care to protect life.
All he wore were heavy hempen robes.

Every summer and autumn, when the sun was high, he would expose his chest, back, thighs, and calves, saying he was feeding mosquitoes, flies, gadflies, leeches, and various insects that bit and sucked his blood until it flowed to the ground.
He practiced like this for more than forty years, never slacking off.
Whenever he met guests, he would only say the two words yi yi, not speaking Chinese at all.
Yet he could understand people's intentions without error.
His hair on top of his head hung down white, and his eyebrows were also long.
